When I was in college I had a sports injury.
I went to see an orthopedist.
He came in, and sat down at my eye level.
He listened to me speak without interrupting.
He said he was sorry I was in pain.
I don't remember much else from that visit.
I'll always remember he really CARED.

Want the same health care as your US senator?
In France, Germany, and Japan, you would.
Everyone is in the same non-profit insurance plans.
There is no managed care or corporate medicine.
There are no HMOs. Patients choose their doctors, and doctors choose the best treatments.

A friend got her doctorate in #nursing.
She took a job at a for-profit #health insurance company.
The first day, her boss told her:
"Just deny 17% of the doctor and hospital claims. I don't care about the facts."
Being a person of noble character, she quit.

I surveyed colleagues in top-rated health care systems FR, DE, CH, and JAP if when they submit their bills to insurance, they get denied.
All of them said that just doesn't happen.
This is the difference of having nonprofit insurance only,
no HMOs, any patient can see any doctor.

I have the best health insurance in the US, Original Medicare plus a supplement to pay copayments.
But, when Medicare--The US Government--won't pay, in come the bills.
They can be massive.
Until we make it law corps can't do this, I will be afraid to go to doctors and hospital.

I advise friends around the world NOT to do what the US has done, putting for-profit corporations in charge of health care.
It has been an unmitigated disaster.
